Cops go all out to put brakes on rogue b.description: KOLKATA: Naka checking, being jointly conducted by local police and traffic cops between 10pm and 1.30am, across 30 crossings in the city and 23 bylanes has revealed that the problem runs deeper than it was initially anticipated. Rogue driving is no more limited to main thoroughfares and it would need a Herculean effort by the cops to sanitize even the narrow alleys that have turned into racing circuits for bikers. The four-hour-long drive saw 607 prosecutions on Wednesday — 205 of them were caught riding without helmets, 315 were challaned for triple-riding. Several others were found riding without a licence or any paper, leading to six bikes being seized. Besides DCPs from the traffic wing, the DCPs from the divisions also monitored these check points. “But the problem goes much beyond dry statistics. We will need a sustained effort to bring the discipline back,” said a senior cop. Lalbazar has instructed its men to keep the campaign going, ensuring the spots are changed and the element of surprise is kept intact for the bikers. A feedback from the 25 traffic guards has shown that the bikers have now moved away from the main roads. “They are not taking the main thoroughfares for two reasons. One, they can avoid CCTV cameras and police checks. Two, if indeed they get caught, they can always claim they were out on a small local errand. Whether it is the Shyambazar-Shyampukur belt in the north or Golf Green-Lords crossing in the south, we need to either penetrate the bylanes or keep an option of chasing down errant riders,” said an officer. According to police, the bikers are well-networked. “Reports of checks from one crossing is reaching youths on bikes several kilometres away. Hence, it is important we penetrate the organized network,” said a source. The cops said that most of the bikers are not the real owners of the vehicles. “On several occasions, we found that people had borrowed bikes from friends, taken it on rent or taken the bike from the local garage for a spin. For this, we will need two things – one, we will need to ensure that the bikes at garages are under leash and two, we need each rider to show us documents pertaining to the bike they are riding,” said an officer. Lalbazar officers also feel the violators who manage to escape one check point is nabbed at the next crossing. “The placement of teams has to be done intelligently. The idea is to set an example. We have seen that bikers, once prosecuted in the early hours of the night, tend to assume that they would not be prosecuted for the same offence again the same day. Hence, they keep violating rules. So, this time, we have decided to seize bikes,” a senior officer at Lalbazar said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. In Video:Govt has taken measures to set up 'chowkidar' in space: PM Narendra Modi in OdishaDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. In Video:Congress refused to forge alliance with AAP for LS polls: KejriwalDownload The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. Snatch the phone and steal the bike:Kolk.description: KOLKATA: Cops busted a gang of motorbike and mobile thieves on Wednesday night and arrested two persons after Anubhav Roy, a resident of Haridevpur and a bike taxi operator lodged a complaint. Inspired by several Facebook and Tiktok troll videos, the gang used to snatch cellphones from bikers. And when the biker chased the snatcher, another person used to run away with the two-wheeler. The duo arrested were identified as Chandan Roy (23) and Raj Das (31). On Wednesday evening, the 24-year-old bike taxi operator was sitting on his motorbike near Balwant Singh Dhaba with a cup of tea when he received a call from a rider. When he was about to take the call, someone pushed him and he fell down. His phone was stolen before he could stand up. “I suspected two youths walking away briskly and challenged them. But they said they had not taken my phone. I identified my ringtone when the phone was ringing in the pocket of one of the youths. The youth ran to an alley and I followed him. Later, I realised that I had left the bike with its key. When I went back, I saw my bike was also stolen,” said the victim. As the sergeants Amit Kumar Shaw, Atanu Nandi and Sujay Pramanik reached the scene, they started questioning people around and visited the lane where the mobile snatcher had run. “The complainant identified the snatcher at a distance and we immediately started grilling him. We found the mobile phone with him and started asking him about his partner. Initially, he refused to give us the answer, but after some time he broke down and told us about the whereabouts of the other youth,” said sergeant Shaw. The police went to another alley guided by the snatcher and after some search they spotted the complainant’s bike parked at a corner of the road. “We waited for the thief to arrive and when he came near the bike around 10 minutes later, we chased him. He tried to run away but it was a blind lane and we could nab him,” said another sergeant. The officers then handed over the thieves to Bhowanipore police station. They were arrested on the basis of the complaint lodged by Roy. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Lalbazar plans night drop for women in d.description: KOLKATA: The SOP that has been prepared by the police in the wake of model Ushoshi Sengupta’s harassment will ensure that no woman or senior citizen is left stranded on the road at night if they approach the police for help. Amongst the various dos and don’ts prepared by Lalbazar, the cops have been reminded that the responsibility of getting a complaint registered at the right police station lies with the responding officer. “But his duty will not end with the filing of the case. The cop will have to ensure that such victims are dropped at their residences safely,” said additional CP (I) Jawed Shamim. Though several instructions regarding filing of FIRs have been standardized, the SOP will help infusing regularity into the system. “The idea of the SOP is to encourage the victims — especially women — to report cases without any fear,” explained another top officer. Sources said that any negligence/deviation from can lead to departmental inquiries. Night policing has been significantly intensified in the city. “Right now, over 100 crime-prone points are being covered under the supervision of senior police officers, particularly to put a check on crime against women at night. Another 50 has been added to the list,” said a police source. In another major decision announced by Shamim, local police will combine with traffic police to carry out night nakas at different locations. “The surprise element has to be maintained. We are expecting to carry out these nakas between 10pm and 1.30am at night,” said a top official. Police officers said they are at a final stage of implementing “sensor cameras” that can trigger alarms at the control room if something grossly wrong is detected. Sanitizing roads tough job, shows Ushosh.description: KOLKATA: Place: Exide crossing. Time: 12:30pm. Around the same time and same place three days ago, model Ushoshi Sengupta was harassed and his app-cab driver was thrashed by bike-borne goons. But on Wednesday, it was a different picture altogether with around 10 uniformed policemen — from Bhowanipore and Maidan police stations — reining in rogue bikers. But those on duty on Wednesday realized soon that they had a tough job at hand. In 15 minutes, more than 20 two-wheelers — either in scooters or in bikes — jumped the red light and whizzed past the police cordon, hardly giving the cops a chance to intercept and prosecute. “In the last two hours, we have prosecuted 58 people but many escaped. One can’t stop them in the middle of the road when they are speeding. It may lead to an accident. Most of the bikers are in their teens and they are driving at over 60 kmph. They are reckless and lack common sense,” said a senior police officer of Bhowanipur police station, who was on duty at Exide crossing. The situation was so scary not only at Exide crossing. Take the example of naka checking at the Dilkhusia Road-Congress Exhibition Road crossing. Hundreds of bikers — mostly teens — could be seen flouting rules. But in one-and-a-half hours, the cops managed to prosecute only 37 people — far below than the actual number of law breakers. “Prosecution alone will not help. People need to understand what is good or bad for them,” an officer said. A biker, a resident of Beliaghata who was prosecuted in front of Beliaghata traffic guard, said: “I went out with my wife to have a late-night dinner. We do this often but we never wear helmets because we hardly find a policeman on the road. The roads are empty and we don’t speed. We did the same thing today but somehow we were intercepted by the police because of special checking.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yoga Day.description: The world marks the fifth edition of International Day of Yoga on June 21, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Here's a look at different yoga styles and its growing popularity worldwide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Kolkata: 2 swine flu cases reported in p.description: KOLKATA: Hospitals in the city continue to get H1N1 positive patients, even as the peak of swine flu is over. At least two of them are being treated for swine flu at present. What is more worrying is that both the patients are from the posh satellite township of Salt Lake. On Thursday another a 71-year-old H1N1 affected, also from Salt Lake died due to HINI pneumonia leading to septic shock causing multi-organ failure. CJ block resident Narayan Krishnamurthi (81) was brought to AMRI Hospital, Salt Lake on June 13. Swab samples tested positive to swine flu. Another patient a resident of AC Block was also admitted to the same hospital with symptoms of swine flu on June 14. Ellora Chaudhuri (47) too has tested positive to H1N1. Conditions of both the patients are critical. Swine flu has already claimed at least 12 lives in the state this year, including two from Salt Lake. A 57-year-old homemaker from BE Block in Salt Lake had died of swine flue on 12 May this year. Even as doctors said that the peak for H1N1 is over and these are only stray cases, residents of Salt Lake are worried with most case are being reported from the township. Three generations from Kalighat family s.description: KOLKATA: The Das family from Kalighat’s Haldarpara is like any other Bengali family, except for one remarkable thing: three generations of this family have served in the country’s armed forces. On June 8, as a proud Col Ashish Das (retd) put epaulets on the shoulders of his son (called ‘pipping’, in military parlance) after the passing-out parade at the Indian Military Academy at Dehra Dun, it was more than a dream come true. Accompanying him was his daughter, already an officer in the Army. The family can serve as an inspiration for the state that gradually earned the reputation of belonging to a ‘non-martial’ race. The colonel’s children are the third generation to serve the country as soldiers. Their grandfather, Late Master Warrant Officer (MWO) B B Das, joined the Royal Indian Air Force and was based in Lahore in 1944 during World War II. He also fought the 1971 Indo-Pak War and went up to Jessore in what was then East Pakistan. He retired from the 253 Signals Unit in Barrackpore. Col Das graduated from St Xavier’s College in Kolkata before joining the Assam Regiment in 1978. In a career spanning nearly 31 years, he was part of counter-insurgency operations across the country. He was also involved in peacekeeping operations with the Indian Peace Keeping Force at Jaffna in Sri Lanka. His exploits along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in Arunachal Pradesh in 1986 prompted the Army to name a high-altitude post there ‘Ashish Top’. He served two tenures at Poonch in Jammu & Kashmir, once when militancy actually started there in 1988-’90. Das retired in 2009 and was appointed director of the Army’s Placement Node in the eastern sector a couple of years later. He continued to head it till 2013. “I have no regrets,” Col Das said. “My daughter joined the Army as a legal officer in 2017 after graduating in law from Dehra Dun. My son is a technical graduate from Bengaluru but opted for an entry in the general stream (he could have opted for the technical stream). He is now an infantry officer in my own regiment. What more can I ask for? My son didn’t even inform me of his plans till after clearing the written exam. He was worried that I would dissuade him as his sister is already in the Army. I can now concentrate on my golf,” the veteran said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. The Times of India does not support or promote piracy in any manner.Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani. Kolkata: Two held for selling drugs to s.description: KOLKATA: Cops have arrested two drug peddlers from the Park Street area on Tuesday night for allegedly selling brown sugar to students and young club goers. Police said the contraband was being sold by the duo from their Royd Street hideout. The persons held by the cops were identified as Sk Latifuddin (37) of Alimuddin Street and Sk Raja (47) of Hussain Shah Road. While around 255gm of brown sugar was seized from Latifuddin at the market cost of Rs 2 lakh, about 20gm of the contraband worth Rs 15,000 was recovered from Raja. “We have been making continuous arrests across the city, especially those operating around schools, colleges and the places where the youngsters hang out. We are booking the accused under NDPS Act. We will arrest more people involved with such offences,” said joint CP (crime) Praveen Tripathi. The duo arrested told cops that they had received orders through WhatsApp andf delivered the contraband to the young addicts. The detective department investigators said the contraband is being spread through lesser known pubs, where students and techies are first lured into consumption of synthetic drugs and then turned into peddlers. Brown sugar is an adulterated form of heroin, is a semi-synthetic opioid, derived from the morphine extracted from poppy plants. These impurities make brown sugar cheaper than more purified form of heroin. Most brown sugar users prefer to smoke the drug, which burns at a lower temperature. Six teaching hosps to get PROs to redres.description: KOLKATA: In a two-pronged strategy, the state has decided to bolster its administration’s soft skills even as it prepares them to tackle any volatile situation. For starters, Kolkata Police sources said all security personnel at the six big government medical college and hospitals in the city—MCH, NRS, RG Kar, CNMC, SSKM and Sagore Dutta—would undergo a mandatory training at the Police Training School for a month. To be instructed by the same set of people who train RAF and Commando forces, the hospital personnel will be taught how to secure wards by not allowing outsiders any entry. But not everything will be about physical prowess. All the government teaching hospitals in Kolkata are set to get proper round-the-clock public grievance redress counters, to be handled by public relations officers. Each of the establishments will get four PROs, who will handle public queries and try to redress their grievances. TOI had reported on Wednesday that these hospitals had only grievance boxes and no dedicated official, as a result of which patients and their families had no one to interact with or turn to in time of distress. “While we focussed on the security aspect during Wednesday’s meet, we had a fruitful discussion on Thursday on how to address public grievances effectively,” said state health secretary Rajiva Sinha. The meeting was held at Swasthya Bhawan, which was attended by Sinha, the six teaching hospitals’ new nodal officers, principals, MSVPs, DME Pradip Mitra and director of health services Ajay Chakraborty. During the May 17 meet with junior doctors before the health service impasse was broken, chief minister Mamata Banerjee had asked health officials to explore the possibilities of deploying officials at every hospital who would redress public grievances and that they should be around all the time. Two new committees have also formed. One of them will look into the upgrade of emergency services and the other will examine how to enhance OPD services. The changes are not likely to be limited to the paper. At NRS, for example, an ACP’s office has been set up right opposite the emergency ward entrance, a step taken not only to boost security but also to send across a message that cops are watching. A dozen security personnel were also seen scanning the visitors to the hospital. Other hospitals have also started working on crowd management. At SSKM Hospital, the emergency area now has a substantial number of cops keeping an eye on visitors. They said all cars parked illegally were being towed away. “The whole idea is to ensure only patients and their families are allowed inside. We are considering whether or not to issue smart tokens to ambulances and all other vehicles carrying in patients and relatives and to ask them to leave the premises within 15 minutes,’’ said a senior police officer. JEE ranks reveal urban-rural divide in s.description: KOLKATA: The results of the West Bengal Joint Entrance Examination (WBJEE) have thrown into light the stark difference of the facilities available to students in mufassil towns and rural areas, and those in urban hubs. While students from rural schools sprang surprises in the higher secondary examination, producing many among the top ten of the merit list, the JEE merit list was dominated by those from urban areas. This has underlined the necessity of a more disciplined and methodical study under experienced teachers focussed on the specialized preparation. According to experts, Apart from schools, coaching institutes play special roles in such performances, where the difference of even one mark can reflect heavily on the rank. This is why students from areas where such coaching is offered tend to fare well in JEE and NEET. Hem Sheela Model School, Durgapur, has done exceedingly well in JEE. Three students of the school managed to be among the top ten — a rare feat. “It is difficult to enlist the reasons for the success. Motivating students by conducting special subject-enrichment classes, individual attention and exposing them to advanced research areas through workshops and seminars could have propelled them to stay focussed,” said Anindita Home Choudhury, principal of the school. Two students from South Point School managed to rank among the top ten. Spokesperson from the school Krishna Damani said, “JEE, IIT entrance and NEET require a lot of specialized training and necessary infrastructure, which are still missing in mufassil towns and rural areas. Though the rural areas have no dearth of talent, they have no access to such facilities and intense practices” Institutes such as Aakash, FIITJEE and Pathfinder, who complement school education with specialized training, revealed that ranking of students under their their care was on the rise. Strategic business unit head of FIITJEE Debdeep Banerjee pointed out that eight students from FIITJEE were in the top ten. FIITJEE has its centres in urban areas like Kolkata and Durgapur. He said, “Our students, thanks to the training we offer, score high in such exams. However, there is discrepancy in the WBJEE, and JEE Advanced ranks of these students.” “Angikar Ghosal, who ranked fourth in JEE, secured AIR 161 in JEE Advanced. If the West Bengal board had a more synchronized approach like the state boards in the north or south, students will gain,” Banerjee added. Pathfinder’s Ashish Chakraborty said although the ranks of their students had risen since last year, they have not been as high as most were preparing for JEE Advanced. He said, “Most students were trying for JEE Advanced as they want to move away from Bengal. Although an integrated system prepares them for all competitive exams, they focus most of their energy on JEE Advanced.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Clash between groups in Kalighat.description: KOLKATA: Tension prevailed near the Kalighat Bazar area as two groups of Trinamool supporters – one owning allegiance to local influential leader Kumar Saha and the other to the local councillor’s son – gheraoed the police station. Both the groups accused each other of promoting drug business in the area. Among the protestors were a large number of women. “ We have spoken to both the groups and decided to carry out periodic raids in the area. We are also increasing our presence in certain pockets,” said a police officer. Local leaders said the party leadership had asked both the groups not to escalate the matter. “Kalighat is a sensitive area and any tension, in run-up to the civic elections, can hurt the prospects of the party. The cops have been asked to take legal action and ascertain the truth,” sources said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Docs\u2019 chat sessions with patients\u.description: KOLKATA: At a time when the lack of trust between doctors and patients has a hit a record high, the gynaecology & obstetrics department at Calcutta National Medical College (CNMCH) sports a different scene altogether. A room, beside the gynaecology emergency, works as the ‘patient party meeting room’. It is a place where the patients’ families can speak about their grievances, seek information and get the status of patients with the doctors themselves attending to each query. “Maa, tomar patient er bleeding kyano hochhe, amra chhobi tule dekchhi aaj (We are investigating why your patient is bleeding),” department head Dr Arati Biswas, tries to reassure Nikita Paik of Paschim Choubaga, whose niece was admitted there on Thursday night. “Once the report is out, we shall decide whether she will undergo normal delivery or caesarean section,” she tells the worried woman. The department has been maintaining this kind of relations with patients for quite some time now. The ‘patient party meeting’ is held twice a day. The morning interaction begins around 11.30am. Patients’ relatives who have queries are requested over the public address system to go to the room. Detailing of all admitted patients is done prior to the meeting. If the department head is not available, senior faculty members and doctors like Mrinal Kanti Kundu and Mallika Datta are present. The presence of senior doctors makes the families feel that the patients are being looked after well. “My sister-in-law was four months into pregnancy when she started bleeding. We were worried as why the treatment was getting delayed. Doctors explained to me that since this was her first pregnancy, they wanted to ensure that she did not lose the child and will discharge her only after they were certain that she was safe. I feel very reassured,” said Buluma Biwi, from Ghatakpukur. The evening meet takes place in between 7pm and 8pm when senior resident doctors and post-graduate trainees address patient families, explaining risks, treatment procedures, condition of the patients, etc. “Communication and free flow of information can help establish a healthy relation between doctors and patients. This department is an example of that,” said Dr Sandip Ghosh, MSVP at CNMCH. In addition to a well-equipped three-bed emergency wing, the 180-bed unit also has six-bed ICU with a transportable ventilator. Despite patient occupancy of nearly double the bed strength, the department has not had any patient-doctor clash. “I am relived to find senior doctors answering my queries and updating me on the status of my wife. Such facilities at all departments, will soothe nerves of anxious patient parties and ease tension between doctors and patients,” said Asgaruddin Sheikh. Swine flu claims Salt Lake man.description: KOLKATA: A 71-year-old Salt Lake resident succumbed to swine flu (H1N1 virus) at a private hospital on Wednesday afternoon. Tapan Kumar Karmakar had been admitted to the hospital on June 14 with high fever and breathing distress. He had been undergoing treatment at the ICU till his death. Doctors at AMRI Hospital Salt Lake, where Karmakar was admitted, said that his death was caused by “H1N1 pneumonia leading to septic shock, causing multi-organ failure.” Three more swine flu patients from Salt Lake have also been undergoing treatment at the private hospital. Several H1N1 deaths have occurred this year. Last year, too, scores of people had been affected in Salt Lake. Once H1N1 strikes, there is a 30%-40% chance of other family members getting affected, say doctors. Transmission happens in two ways with the droplets released by the patient through cough and sneeze as well as one’s contact with the patient’s clothes. Sonagachhi sex workers to sell grocery,.description: KOLKATA:Sonagachhi, the city’s biggest red-light area, is all set to get a department store for the sex-workers and their family. The store, ‘Usha consumer stores’, on Nilmoni Mitra Street is scheduled to be inaugurated on Friday. Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC), an NGO that works for the welfare and development of sex workers, has taken this initiative along with Usha Multipurpose Cooperative Society Limited, mainly keeping the ageing sex workers and the children. Chief advisor of DMSC Smarajit Jana said, “This attempt will create alternate ways of earning for the ageing sex workers , who wish to leave the profession as well as make the children financially independent by providing job opportunities.” He added it would help include them in mainstream and fight their own battles. The store will have wide range of goods, from groceries, medicines, household goods and electronics at a reasonable rate. Shatabdi Saha, deputy manager of Usha Multipurpose Cooperative Society Limited said, “As the women work till late at night, it is difficult for them to visit the markets in the morning. The store will also have home delivery system.” Ratan Dolui, son of a sex worker , feels this initiative would help them cope with the social stigma that the children faced due to their mother’s profession and be accepted as part of the mainstream society. Nita Das (name changed), a sex worker in her 40s, said, “At my age, it is difficult to get work but I have to support my family. This will be an alternative mode of earning. ” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Punish guilty, shed \u2018shielding\u201.description: KOLKATA: Prominent Muslims in Kolkata have urged Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee to act decisively against people of their community who were involved in crime as that would help overcome the “perception” that they are being “shielded or appeased”. Muslims from various walks of life, who have been living in Kolkata for decades, highlighted two recent incidents: the NRS Medical College and Hospital violence last Monday and the hounding of model Ushoshi Sengupta and her app cab driver in the city this Monday. The accused, in both cases, were arrested within 24 hours of the incidents. “The attackers in both instances were members of our community. We are grieved and embarrassed. Bring the assailants to book not just in these two instances but in every single instance where Muslims are involved. They should not be allowed to get away because they happen to be Muslims (as is the growing perception). This will send out a message that members of one community are not being shielded or appeased (as most people bel-ieve),” the letter — signed by 46 prominent Muslim citizens of Kolkata — states. They have also urged the state government to engage or encourage engagements with Muslim youth and their families across Kolkata in gender-sensitisation, civic consciousness and law-compliance. “This requires long-term patience but needs to be implemented right away,” the letter says. Psychologist Zahid H Ganjee, one of the signatories, said: “There have been several lynching cases in the past year-and-a-half and sane voices from the Hindu community have demanded justice. Unfortunately, Muslims have not said and done enough when members of the community have acted like rogues. This has led to the entire community being tarnished. I hope the letter will spark a conversation, even a debate and then something good will come out of it. We are losing our primary identity as a citizen of this country and state. We need to reclaim it.” Abdul Rahim, who runs an NGO, stressed the need for the community to receive fair and not privileged treatment. “There is a growing perception that the administration here is soft on Muslims who break the law. This perception needs to change. We want the law to be enforced without considering religious identity,” he said. Communications expert Mudar Patherya, who drafted the letter after a discussion with several of the signatories, said there had been simmering discontent for some time. “I will not comment on whether the perception (that the administration is soft on Muslims) is right or wrong. But I feel, till now, governments have looked at the next vote and not the next generation. The moment they do that, things will change positively. I believe Muslims need to take a position,” he said. Rahim says the administration needs to reach out to the community in the ghettos and strengthen, educate and empower the youth. “If you consider each of the incidents, the culprits hailed from ghettos,” he said. Most of the signatories feel the recurring crime by Muslim youths is to do with poverty and illiteracy in ghettos where they reside. Mamoon Akhtar, who runs a school (Samaritan Help Mission) in Tikiapara, says children can bring about great change if educated. But the letter has also drawn flak from a section of the community. Nutritionist Neha Hafiz, another signatory, took pains to point out that it was not a missive against the Trinamool government or its treatment of Muslims; but there was a need to change the perception that was being created about the community receiving more privileges than others. “There is a problem. We cannot deny it. And it needs to be addressed. Blaming anyone does not help. There is a need for education and reforms,” she said. West Bengal violence: Two dead, 12 injur.description: KOLKATA: Reeling under series of violent clashes over a month Bhatpara on Thursday faced a fresh spate of violence with at least two persons being killed and 12 more persons, including six policemen were injured. 17-year old Rambabu Shaw, and a jute mill worker Dharam Veer Shaw were killed by an unidentified mob when an unidentified group opened fire at Kachharibazar in Kakinada. The incident, which came hours before DGP Virendra’s visit to inaugurate Bhatpara police station, prompted the government to impose section 144 IPC in Bhatpara and Jagaddal. The tension mounted on Thursday morning when two bombs were hurled near the reliance jute mill when the workers were going to join a shift around 10.45 am. Locals alleged that a group of men threw bombs first and then started beating up men and women who were trying run for their lives. When residents of Bhatpara More area came out and chased them, the group ran towards Kachhari Bazar area. “There were children playing on the street and we started to vacate the area near West Ghosh Para Road fearing a fresh attack,” said Dhiraj Paswan, a local. By 11.15 am there was another spate of bombing at Kachhari Bazar area. Locals at the Kachhari Road area came out and rushed towards the main road when they saw police chasing them. “Somebody opened fire and at least five fell on the road,” said Bhairon Pandey. Locals said that they heard several rounds of gunshots. Police had to use tear gas shells to control the groups. The teenager identified as Rambabu Sahu, a pani puri seller was shot and succumbed to his injuries. BJP leader and Barrackpore MP Arjun Singh alleged that the teenager was hit when police opened fire. “The bullet had hit him on the head. Apart from that seven more persons were injured,” Singh said. Trinamool Congress leader Madan Mitra however claimed that police fired in the air to scare the attackers. “BJP is creating a terror in these areas after the polls. The guilty should be punished otherwise the situation will go beyond control,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Monsoon likely to arrive in Kolkata toda.description: KOLKATA: The wait for monsoon is likely to end on Friday. After a delay of more than a week the Met office have finally traced monsoon clouds that are likely to burst open over the Kolkata skies on Friday, 13 days after the Southwest monsoon hit the Kerala coast. “The prevailing weather conditions are favourable for the monsoon to finally hit Kolkata. Monsoon clouds are already over the Bay of Bengal area. Along with this, a low pressure area over the Northeast Bay has given us the hope for the rains to hit Kolkata and other parts of south Bengal by Friday,” said G K Das, director (weather) at Regional Meteorological Centre, Kolkata. The Southwest monsoon reached the Kerala coast on June 8, seven days later than its scheduled date. Usually, the scheduled date for the monsoon to arrive in Kolkata is June 10, with an error margin of four days. In 2018, it hit Kolkata on June 11, 13 days later. In 2017, monsoon kept its date with the city on June 12, again 13 days after its onset in Kerala. If it hits the city on Friday, as predicted by the Met office, it will maintain its 13-day gap between its arrival in Kerala and Kolkata. Monsoon has already covered parts of Cooch Behar and Alipurduar. By Thursday, it had also touched some parts of neighbouring South and North 24 Pargans. By Friday, it is expected to cover more places, including Kolkata, north and south Bengal. “The low pressure area over the Northeast Bay is likely to come close to the coast by Thursday night and gradually move inside the land. Once it happens, it will bring in the monsoon rain. Meanwhile, there will be moderate rain in many places over the coastal area,” Das added. But before the monsoon arrives, Kolkata continues to swelter with the mercury remaining as high as three degrees above the normal mark at 35.9 degrees Celsius on Friday. If monsoon arrives on Friday, the temperature is likely to recede by about two degrees by Friday. “I hope the wait for monsoon does not get any longer. The heat is becoming unbearable at times,” said Sayani De, a schoolteacher. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

India Pakistan news.description: NEW DELHI/ISLAMABAD: India dismissed on Thursday as "fake news" the suggestion in Pak media that it was looking to resume talks with the hostile neighbour and asserted that there was no dilution of its position that Islamabad needed to take verifiable and irreversible action against terrorism for the dialogue to resume. Responding to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's congratulatory letter after he assumed office for the second time, PM Narendra Modi wrote back on June 12 expressing India's desire to have normal and cooperative relations with all its neighbours, including Pakistan, while stressing that "for this, it is important to build an environment of trust, free of terror, violence and hostility". Foreign minister S Jaishankar also wrote to his Pakistani counterpart S M Qureshi, again only in response to the latter's congratulatory letter, emphasising the need for an atmosphere "free from the shadow of terror and violence". The emphasis on the need for Pakistan to rein in terror as a pre-condition for re-engagement was in keeping with the stand which saw Modi refrain from engaging with Imran Khan at the just-concluded SCO summit in Kyrgyzstan. Yet, the Pakistani media chose to interpret the contents of the letters of Modi and Jaishankar as reflecting India's desire to re-engage. The foreign ministry in Delhi quickly scotched the suggestion. "There was complete distortion and an attempt to peddle fake news (in the way it was reported). The letters only reiterated India's old position that it wants normal and cooperative relations with all countries in South Asia and that it was important to create an environment free of terror and violence for it. There was no mention of any sort of dialogue with Pakistan," said MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar, adding that India will not be fooled by any cosmetic action against terror by Islamabad. Emphasising that both the letters were written in as per the "established diplomatic practice", Kumar said: "In their messages, they have highlighted that India seeks normal and cooperative relations with all neighbours, including Pakistan." In his letter, Modi had said that India remained committed to operationalising early an "all-year-round" Kartarpur corridor. Touching upon it, Kumar said India had already held three technical-level discussions with Pakistan and was currently awaiting clarification from Islamabad over a few issues it had raised. Puzzlingly, later in the evening, Pakistan's foreign ministry, which had kept quiet through the day, also sought to play down the speculation about the import of the letters. While responding to a question, the spokesperson said, "It was an established practice for the leadership to congratulate new office holders and for them to respond." "Pakistan's position on the way forward in relations with India was clear and well-known and did not require repetition," said the spokesperson, adding that the "vision of peace, progress and prosperity of South Asia could be advanced by peacefully resolving all outstanding disputes, including Jammu & Kashmir, and moving away from dynamic of confrontation to cooperation". Earlier in the day, sources in the Pakistan foreign office had said that Modi and Jaishankar had responded positively to recent letters from their Pakistani counterparts by conveying New Delhi's desire to engage with all countries, including Pakistan, for elimination of terrorism and prosperity of the region. "India has always prioritised peace and human development, and sought to maintain cordial relations with all regional powers," Modi and Jaishankar maintained, according to FO sources. Both leaders, according to FO sources, called for special attention on elimination of terrorism in the region and said the issue must be a core focus in all future talks. They have also appreciated sentiments from Pakistan in their letters, the FO sources added. Modi's letter was in response to a congratulatory letter from Khan in which he had underscored Pakistan's vision of working for "durable peace and stability in South Asia with peaceful resolution of all outstanding disputes, including J&K". Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Bali draws 22k travellers from Kolkata e.description: Bali: Withdrawal of direct flights to Bali from Kolkata has done little to diminish the wanderlust for the island destination among city travellers. For the past few years, Bali has been one of the most favoured places among Kolkatans as the Indonesian archipelago offers something for travellers of all ages. Although June to September is the best time to visit Bali, the popularity of the place, thanks to social media, has made it an all-year-round favourite with over 22,000 people from Kolkata visiting the beach hotspot every year. “Cancellation of the direct AirAsia flight has not affected tourist flow to Bali. In fact, the traveller count has increased over time. Now, passengers fly via Bangkok or Singapore to reach the Indonesian island. All flights travelling to Bali on average clock 60-70% occupancy,” said Anil Punjabi, regional (east) chairman of the Travel Agents’ Federation of India. Since the beach city offers visa-on-arrival facility, more travellers are seen preferring it to other nearby tourist destinations such as Maldives and Mauritius, he said. “Bali, with its boutique resorts, is also popular for honeymoon and weddings.” Didit Indra Purnawarman, the general manager of Bali Dynasty Resort, feels the tourist hotspot offers something for people from all segments with an array of restaurants, bars, swimming pools and nightclubs. Another agent from the city said Pujas and the summers witness maximum rush. “Around 450 to 500 people from Kolkata travelled to Bali between March and May this year. It has a yearlong traction since it is a low-budget international destination. Also, the island city is on high demand since a lot of people are now selecting Bali as a destination wedding location over Thailand,” Ankit Jain, business development manager, Raj Yatayat. Bali provides a healthy mix of modern and traditional attractions such as beach, jungles, volcanic destinations and yoga retreats. Among the beaches, Nusa Dua is one of the most prominent ones, known for its inclusive tourism, as it houses some of the best world-class resorts, mostly owned by international hotel chains. Also, one should not miss beaches like Kuta, Legian, Seminyak, Jimbaran, Sannur and Canggu. Oriol Montal, the general manager of The Westin Resort in Nusa Dua, said: “The resort has a prime beachfront location within an exclusive enclave on the island’s southern shores catering to the needs of leisure and business travellers alike.” For coffee connoisseurs, a cup of Kopi Luwak, one of the costliest brews (a 50gm pack costs around Rs 1,000) made of beans that have been partially digested by the Asian palm civet, is a must try. (The journalist was in Bali on an invitation by VITO India and Thai Airways Kolkata) Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Ushoshi Sengupta assault case: Easy acce.description: KOLKATA: The gang of 10 youths which had followed Kolkata-based model Ushoshi Sengupta’s app cab on the streets of south Kolkata before hounding her — not once but twice — late on Monday night was not new to such hooliganism. In fact, these youths, who took up odd jobs at garages and markets, picked up any bike or car that they could lay their hands on for their late-night rides. “They would often go out at night — thanks to their access to garages. They would triple-ride and not wear helmets. Any vehicle approaching their direction had to give them way, failing which the drivers or riders would be subjected to harassment and abuses. These joyrides often became their only escape from boredom,” recalled Md Fayaz, a local residing at the CIT building located close to Navina Cinema. Top police sources said around 25 people had gone to attend a birthday party at a hotel close to Park Circus. “There was a car, a scooter, two motorcycles and an autorickshaw that was not on duty at the time. Some of them took the Sarat Bose Road. Others came via the Exide crossing,” said an officer. He said barely few in the group even had the requisite documents to ride or drive on the streets. Police said none of the accused had a criminal history. “It is this culture of not being stopped at any security check post despite not wearing helmets or riding recklessly that might have encouraged these youths to chase and harass the model travelling in a car,” said a retired ACP from the anti-rowdy squad. Speaking to TOI, most of the accused’s neighbours, who refused to be identified said that the families of the youths had asked not to be disturbed. “Your version of events has already been decided. All we know is that our boys had gone out to celebrate a birthday. A brand new scooter was hit by the app cab. The rear-view mirror was broken. The youths might have demanded money for repairs of the scooter. We might not be financially not well off, but we believe that the model was not harmed,” said the mother of an accused. Seven of the accused are already in police net, while Three of them are on the run. When TOI knocked on the doors of the accused and inquired about their whereabouts, the families informed “He is not at home”. “We want things to cool down a bit. I am told the cops are searching for youths with bikes. My son does not mix with them (the accused). But one cannot be sure,” said Sk Badruddin, a butcher. The locals claimed that there were not more than three men the second time the model was harassed near her residence at Lake Gardens. “Why are so many youngsters being blamed for this crime?” an officer said. CBSE\u2019s magic eight in WBJEE top-10;.description: Kolkata: Eight of the top 10 rank-holders at the 2019 West Bengal Joint Entrance Examination (WBJEE) are headed to IITs. And the toppers all hail from urban centres, a pointer to the importance of specialized coaching. Eight of the top 10 studied in CBSE schools, and one each were from ISC and HS boards, underscoring the dominance of the central board in competitive examinations. Soham Mistri, a student of Hem Sheela Model School in Durgapur, has stood first. Two other students from the school figure in the top 10: third rank-holder Koustav Sen and 10th rank-holder Subhajyoti Ghosh. The seventh rank-holder, Vinit Raj, is from Burnpur Riverside School in Chittaranjan, not far away. The rest are all from Kolkata, including second rank-holder Tamajit Banerjee and fourth rank-holder Angikar Ghoshal from South Point School, and sixth rank-holder Snehinh Sen from DPS Ruby Park. Only one of the toppers — fifth rank-holder Arka Das of Sarada Vidyapith, Sonarpur — is from the HS board an improvement from last year, when none made it to the list. A matter of concern is that the number of successful candidates (those who scored higher than 0) has plummetted from 1,05,081 last year to 80,580. Though 1,13,912 students registred for the exam, 80,979 appeared. Last year, 1,05,974 had registered. The reason for the massive decline in the number of students who appeared this year is primarily owing to a month’s delay in holding the exam due to the Lok Sabha elections. Most other competitive exams had already been held by the time WBJEE was conducted. Academics also say there is a general decline in the demand for engineering, because of a limitation in job opportunities. This is reflected in the WBJEE board’s decision to scrap the fourth round of counselling that was introduced a few years ago and return to three rounds of counselling. “The response had been poor among candidates to join engineering courses after the end of three rounds, as most of the vacant seats then were in lesser known engineering colleges. Another reason is the time constraint this year, as the entrance test and publication of results have been pushed back by a month due to the Lok Sabha elections,” said a board member. The late publishing of results may also lead to vacancy in undergraduate classes in colleges, particularly in the science stream, as many students who have taken admission and have secured a good rank at WBJEE will now switch to engineering institutes. Classes in colleges is set to begin in the first week of July. Aware of the impending exodus to IITs and other engineering institutes across the country, the WBJEE board has decided to allow all candidates who have scored above 0 to participate in e-counselling. “We are yet to receive the seat matrix as All-India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) is in the process of trimming the seats and departments which are not meeting the set standards. Last year, there were around 35,000 engineering seats in Bengal,” an official said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Four La Martiniere governors sacked for.description: KOLKATA: The four governors of the La Martiniere Schools board, who protested against the removal of secretary Shane Calvert and the reinstatement of Supriyo Dhar, by challenging Bishop Paritosh Canning in writing, have been removed from their positions. A letter issued to them stated that their appointments stand cancelled with immediate effect. The letter has been signed by two ex-officio governors — Canning and Swarup Bar. The governors — Anil Mukherji, COO of Tollygunge Club, Suchitra Guha of Tata Steel, Anjali Das of United Missionary and Gerry Arathoon, chief of the Council for Indian School Certificate Examinations — called the move “illegal” and have decided to move court. They had been nominated in March by former bishop Probal Dutta. The present administration, headed by Canning, found the manner in which the nominations were conducted “inappropriate”. Hence the decision to revoke the nominations. The letter was issued on Wednesday on the basis of a meeting convened on Tuesday. The four governors sent their protest letters to the Bishop on Tuesday evening. In his protest letter on Tuesday, Gerry Arathoon had written: “I ... understand that the purported termination of Mr Calvert’s services has been made without any allegation or charge against him and without informing him as to why his services were no longer required or affording him an opportunity of being heard in connection with the same.” Regarding Wednesday’s letter, Mukherji said: “It is arbitrary. Why couldn’t they say what kind of irregularities they found in our nominations? What is it that they exactly mean by procedure? We will challenge this legally.” Guha, too, said: “They have removed us because we are protesting against their whimsical ways. But there is a constitution that needs to be followed and we will fight back.” Canning was in Delhi and did not receive calls, but the letter of removal of the four governors is in possession of TOI. “There are age-old conventions that need to be followed while making these nominations, but these were ignored by Dutta. So the four governors have been removed,” said a senior official of the Bishop’s House. Meanwhile, Canning has moved the HC to obtain a stay on the order of the city civil court regarding his inclusion as a party to the suit of former Bishop Ashoke Biswas against the Church of North India for removing him from his position. The HC has stayed the order. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Kolkata girl gets rape threat on Faceboo.description: KOLKATA : A second-year college student has approached the cyber cell of Kolkata Police after receiving rape-and-death threats on her social network account. The threats followed within minutes of uploading her views last Sunday, condemning the enmity that spreads every time India face Pakistan in a cricket match. “Within minutes of me posting that I will remain as much a Shoaib Akhtar fan as a Yuvraj Singh one, comments started to pour in. Initally, the trolls attacked me on cricketing logic. As comments began to get more personal, I pointed out that I would support the better playing team — India or Pakistan. This seemed to be the limit after which extremely offensive memes — calling me names and issuing rape threats — were uploaded,” she said. The girl said that among those trolling him were college students and even Facebook groups dedicated to extreme right wing organizations. “They were the same people who took offence after my Pulwama-related post and got my profile blocked when I raised a few basic questions,” she claimed. Unable to bear the online abuse that began on June 16, the 22-year-old decided to approach police for help. What she faced there left her disheartened. “The cop at the desk refused to hear me out. He said that some of the comments were anti-national in nature and that they can indeed attract trolls. He, however, finally accepted my complaint and a general diary was drawn. I have been told that I will be informed if and when the FIR is filed,” she said. The reluctance of cops to pursue the case — that too at the police headquarters at Lalbazar — has left several activists aghast. “We will stand by her,” said a senior member from APDR. The cops though denied that they had not accepted her complaint. “We merely tried explaining to her the legal ramifications of this case and the sections that can be imposed. She had demanded action on certain non-corgnizable offences,” explained an officer. CID sources said their probe into online trolling has so far found several groups active on Facebook who “choose their targets on the anti-national plank.” “These groups are targeting individuals differing from their opinion and instigating others to join them online. We have approached the social networking giants to develop leads about them,” claimed a source. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\u2018Women\u2019s security a priority o.description: KOLKATA: Attending the 64th Railway Week celebrations in the city on Wednesday, Metro Railway GM P C Sharma indicated that women’s security will be a priority on Metro trains. He also said the construction for the East-West Metro Corridor was on in full swing and Phase I — between Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium — was set to be commissioned in the next few months. “Providing security to women is a challenging issue. In 2018-2019, we detected 12 cases of crime against women in the Metro Railway network and 22 offenders were handed over to the police. In addition to this, 4,035 cases of nuisance, spitting, smoking and littering were registered between April 1, 2018 and March 31, 2019. A fine of Rs 10,46,750 was realized from the offenders,” Sharma said, indicating that authorities have their task cut out in keeping the station premises and trains on the E-W Corridor clean. The GM also said that efforts were on to complete the link to Dakshineswar by 2019-2020. This short stretch missed its deadline by several years due to delay in the removal of encroachers. Sharma spoke on construction along the Noapara-Airport stretch. “Construction of the airport underground yard is under way. Work on all 294 piles and the 1,215m diaphragm wall has been completed. At all 24 stations, 1,620 employees have been trained on use of fire suppression equipment,” he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Haringhata cannon could be of Plassey vi.description: HARINGHATA: The recovery of what could possibly be a six-pounder cannon used in the Battle of Plassey from the Yamuna canal at Nadia’s Haringhata on Wednesday has led to excitement among locals with hundreds flocking to the local police station to catch a glimpse of the antique piece of artillery. The Battle of Plassey was fought on June 23, 1757 and the discovery was made nearly 262 years later to date. According to Haringhata BDO Krishna Gopal Dhara, the cannon is very old. The weapon is made of brass and it is nearly 4 feet 2 inches in length. History has it that Robert Clive used eight six-pounders apart from two howitzers during the decisive battle against the forces of Nawab Siraj-ud-Daulah. Historians believe recovery of cannon while restoration of the Yamuna canal is also significant. At that time, an intricate network of canals existed in the area and the Yamuna canal was dug to connect the Ganga to the Padma and the Ichhamati. Some say Clive’s troops may have used the canal to travel to and from Plassey, about a 112-km from Haringhata. Such small cannons, used to fire balls weighing about six-pounds (2.7 kg) were used extensively across the globe in the 18th and 19th Centuries, primarily due to their manoeuvrability. In the Battle of Plassey, Clive is said to have flanked the European troops with three six-pounders on each side while placing the remaining two and the howitzers behind some brick kilns to take on the French troops, who were fighting alongside Siraj-ud-Daulah. While the Nawab too used artillery guns, they were of heavier calibre. “It was found at South Rajapur. While one end of the cannon is 17-inches in diameter, the body tapers to end up with a 12-inch base. There is also a handle to fix the cannon to base, either on a carriage or the deck of a boat. We have kept the item in our custody and informed the Archaeological Survey of India so that experts come and examine it,” said Ashoktaru Mukherjee, IC, Haringhata police station. Locals also speak of a Nil Kuthi in Haringhata, possibly occupied by indigo planters. This property had a ghat and British craft used to move along the canal to get there. But they can’t say whether indigo planters would need a six-pounder to deal with poor peasants. “The cannon must have some historic significance and needs to be preserved properly after inspection by experts. We just hope that after proper cleaning and repairs, it is displayed prominently somewhere in Haringhata with a plaque for everybody to see,” said Manik Das, a local. Attacks on doctors, model: Prominent Kol.description: KOLKATA: In the wake of the attack on doctors and harassment of model Ushoshi Sengupta by some members of their community, a group of prominent Muslims has written to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee asking for stringent action against the culprits to dispel the "perception" that they are being "shielded or appeased". "We have been deeply concerned with two events that occurred recently...The attackers in both instances were members of our community...We are grieved and embarrassed," they wrote in the letter. "Bring the assailants to book not just in these two instances but in every single instance where Muslims are involved. They should not be allowed to get away because they happen to be Muslims (as is the growing perception). This will send out a message that members of one community are not being shielded or appeased (as most people believe)," the 46 prominent Muslim residents of Kolkata added. They also requested the state government to "engage or encourage engagements with Muslim youth and their families across Kolkata in gender-sensitisation, civic consciousness and law-compliance, etc." Mudar Patherya, a communications expert who drafted the letter to Banerjee, said a government should shun vote-bank politics and address the issue considering the betterment of the next generation. "The moment they start doing that, I think things will start taking a positive turn for us," he said. Another signatory, nutritionist Neha Hafiz, said there is a need to change the perception that the community was "getting more privileges than others". "This is a problem that we cannot deny. We need to address it," she added. On June 10, junior doctors at the Nil Ratan Sircar Medical College and Hospital were assaulted by family members of a Muslim patient who died there.
